moves.6... Be7 7. e3 a6 8. Be2 O-O 9. O-O Na5: c6 causes Black's N to become trapped.
Now Black has structural weaknesses--two sets of doubled pawns that will be vulnerable.  Offsetting that is temporary control of the b file.
moves.16. Rab1: Fighting for the b file immediately.
moves.16... Rxb1: Bb7 might have been slightly better, but the B would have been a lousy piece there.
moves.17. Rxb1 Bh4: Not sure of the rationale for this move.  Generally, Black would want to avoid trades when behind in material.
moves.18. Nxh4 Qxh4 19. Bxa5 Qf6 20. Bc7 Re8 2: The d6 Bishop now keep the c8 Bishop out of play.  Black is effectively two pieces down.
moves.21... Qg5 22. Qd1 a5 23. Rb8 g6 24. Ra8: This was unnecessarily complex.  Bb7 would have worked just fine.
moves.27... a4 28. Bxd7 Rxb8 29. Bxb8 Qd8: Already ahead in material, White will now gain several passed pawns at the cost of the Bishop.
Forces the exchange of Queens.  Black's King alone will be unable to stop the pawns running free.
Now Black's King is tied down to the a-pawn.  White's f3 prepares for yet another passed pawn.
moves.43... g5 44. e4 fxe4 45. fxe4 g4 46. e5: Black's King cannot stop all of the passers, especially with the Bishop helping out from the rear.
